finished a nice 5 day trip in Paris. saw lots of old pretty buildings and ate french food. it is really a beautiful city and i found the people to be really friendly, even though my french sucks. it was also great seeing my friends. currently in stockholm visiting a friend. i have been here before and already did the tourist stuff so now i can just hang out. great weather too. currently at an internet cafe at hötorget tubestop.

had an amazing meal somewhere, i think around the bastille. an enormous dish of shellfish and a lot of white wine. really fantastic - and we were all treated by a good friend of carine's. i wish i could remember the name of that place ... i'll have to ask.

Check out of the Hotel de l'Academie and have a brunch and stroll in Le Marais area. Then C leaves for the airport and I move to my new hotel, the "Hotel le Plan d'Etait", which is near Republique. Not nearly as charming as the last place and I'm still making up my mind about this neighborhood/location, but I suppose a walk around will give a better idea. anyway, i'm still downtown and the room is clean.

Day 2 in Paris. Coffee in the morning on Blvd St. Germain and then we take the metro to Les Halles to have lunch with Carine. We go to a Moroccan restaurant and have a really nice meal. Then C and I go to the Musee d' Orsay and spend a few hours walking around the galleries. She knows quite a bit about art. I don't, but it was really interesting anyway. Dinner tonight involved looking for an african restaurant called "Omar" near the Republique. Unfortunately the internet connection went down before we could get an address. So we walk forever around the Republique, asking taxi drivers, concierges, etc. One concierge does not know of "Omar" but mentions another african place called "Dogon" just around the corner. we have a look from the corner and decide it is uninspiring. keep walking and looking for "Omar". Finally give up and ask for other restaurant rec's. Almost go to the first place, "Chez Jenny", but it is a bit expensive so we decide to give "Dogon" another shot. We walk up to the restaurant entrance of Dogon and see one guy sitting at the otherwise empty bar. We decide it is closed and walk away. He sees C's union jack umbrella and comes to the door, saying "It's really good! The food here is great! Are you from London? " We walk cautiously back and find out that it's not closed, but the restaurant is upstairs. we walk cautiously upstairs and then are relieved to see a dining area full of people. The man from the bar, Alpha, and his friend, an English teacher in Paris, join us for dinner. He is senegalese, educated in Paris, and living in London as a French & spanish professor. She has just gotten the results from a difficult teacher's inspection and tells us about the process. Sounds very very strict. We spend 2+ hours talking and eating and drinking. I think they are interested in what we do at work. Finally we head back around 1:30am. A really great night.

Day 1 in Paris. Arrive at Gare du Nord and wait for a taxi. Lots of traffic. Get to the Hotel de l'Academie, which is in the Latin Quarter/St. Germain area. Really beautiful surroundings. Our room is so small, I can barely see it. C arrives around 9pm, as expected. We go out to dinner in the nearby area. Appetizers were awesome, main course was alright. Fixed price of 14 euros. A friend of the restaurant staff sat down to chat as we were finishing the meal. He was really nice at first, and more than a bit sleazy later, hitting like mad on my friend. They invite us to a nightclub but we decline.

Latest from Burma is that Aung San Suu Kyi is being held in Insein Prison, just in time for her 58th Birthday. No sign of release from this "protective custody", which apparently is the same as being in jail. She has no access to a legal process, since Burma has no such thing. Her vehicle was attacked by goverment-sponsored thugs at a recent speech in northern Burma, and they jailed her and several other members of the NLD, blaming them for the violence. At the recent ASEAN conference, neighboring nations condemned her imprisonment but said nothing about imposing sanctions. The US is quite serious about furthering sanctions and freezing assets of the Burmese military junta's leaders; however, since the US doesn't trade a whole lot with Burma, the effects would not be as great as sanctions imposed by other SE Asian countries.

when i was staying in mexico, i found one of urlLink these in my room (!!). I would say its body was a good three+ inches, and with legs (not counting the superlong feeler-antennae legs) it was around 7 or 8 inches in diameter. i had a late night out and got home around 3am. the mexican family i was staying with kept the drains covered so as to prevent insects from entering. i saw my bathroom sink drain lid had been moved so i went around my room, armed with one sneaker, looking for a big cockroach or something. i did a double take then a horrific recoil to find this on the wall of my clothes-hanging alcove space. i hovered over it with the shoe and then it ran very very quickly, sideways. Then i snuck up on it and beat it senseless. It died several times. turns out to be a creature called a tailless whipscorpion or whipspider; or more exactly, a member of the order Amblypygi. they are harmless to humans but are also huge and gross-looking. urlLink Here is a good story about a field trip encounter with one of these, found in a cave, eating a frog.

a last minute airport thought to get a "meow-lingual" cat translation device resulted in the following conversation: me: hi, i'm looking for a cat translator called "meow-lingual" clerk: shows me the english/japanese electronic dictionaries me: no, it's for cats. so you know what they're saying. it's made in japan. clerk: for cats and dogs to use? i'm sorry, we don't have anything like that. me: no, it's so i can understand them. it's a toy. clerk: you want cat food? me: not cat food. cat translator. you know, "cat": "neco" [japanese for cat]. then i mimicked a cat saying "meow" and me holding out a device near it. i think they understood. anyway, either that or they were fed up with me. i was pointed to the next row of shops.

cool thing i did this week: [actually yesterday.] saw, for free, david foster wallace get interviewed by george saunders (both are authors). they talked about writing and answered audience questions. audience members were mostly writing students who asked super geeky questions that took longer to ask than to answer. interesting things the authors discussed: +having sean hannity as a character, and writing with an eye for understanding and empathizing with him +why do teachers say "write what you know"? otherwise they get very strange scifi-ish things. on the flip side, the request can result in generic crap. but also mentioned that you know more than you think and can prob. extrapolate your experiences to connect with a particularly strange-but-trueish character +self-aware/neurotic attributes of writers +self-collapsing genres who connect with their own kind better than the public, thereby turning their energy inwards quite worth mentioning: 4 bad trendy consecutive male haircuts in the row front of us. I will try to remember them in order: "freeze-frame, bed-head", "curly, unshaven, shaggy with hat" (may not be so trendy actually), "slight mullet", "sculpted rock star with elfin sidelocks".

after reading urlLink my roommate's blog about life in korea , it reminds me of things that i thought were weird about japan. like how it's okay to be shitfaced throwing up in public [actually it seems like you can do and say anything you want iff you're drunk], and how people think it's cute if you like parts of their culture or language. i probably didn't have to deal with it as much as he does because i made little attempt regarding the language. but i would get the occasional not-funny joke if i knocked something over in the cramped office - "oh, you're used to america - lots of room! japan is too small." which i think they meant to be self-deprecating but actually wasn't at all. i think i learned some things too, about how to fit too many objects neatly in a very small space, how NOT to plan and proceed through events (very confusing with lots of papers and hands flying, and a good deal of nonsense logic), and how to work with their extreme devotion to harmony (aka how to get your way, nicely.). where i probably should have learned more but didn't: india. too many people, animals, cars, dust. too little toilet paper. virtues include: patience, persistence. annoyances include: slowness, harassment. still wondering if i learned something: mexico, thailand. wait, someone did tell me the four something-or-others of buddhism in a car ride once thru bangkok. don't remember it but apparently all your life's events can fit into one of these four categories. and in mexico i learned spanish (not life-shattering but at least measurable)

tonight i saw joao gilberto at carnegie hall. he played "corcovado", "desafinado", "garota de ipanema" (of course), "pra que discutir com madame", "estate" (i was thrilled), "sandalia de prata", "doralice", and 2 hours worth of songs whose names i forget. the crowd was (mostly) completely quiet while he played, and the quality of the sound was amazing, even from my nearly-as-high-up-as-you-can-be seat. for the whole set it was just him and his guitar. he sounded exactly like the voice i've been hearing for years on CD. just perfect.

..or.."a few months past planting season, i decide to do something about my yard." making my way home from union square's weekend market: first get a taxi. not easy since i have to transport a small fortune in medium sized plants. hide the plants away from the curb where they will be out of sight to an approaching car (a truck was right next to me so that obscured the view). taxi pulls up and i wait for him to stop and open the trunk before carting everything over, with the help of a gold-toothed lanky (suspected) chinese nursery assistant. second drive the short distance to my house. on the way the driver asks if i am married, i say no; he says he thought i might be because "it is usually married women who are getting the trees and plants and things." i suddenly feel prematurely domesticated. i mean, if he only knew how little planning went into this day of yard work, that i started out just sweeping the patio and then thought to get some big pots, then plants, then dirt - at any step with no intention of really completing it all that day, or perhaps ever; and then all the sweat that was involved in ripping out fifteen foot sumac seedlings and hauling bags of dirt and digging and et cetera, maybe he would not have said that. i'm really confounded by that statement actually. third, i actually finish it all before dark. the next morning there was one attempted suicide of a flowerbox, which had thrown itself to the ground, as it wasn't mounted that well. hung it back up and am keeping an eye on it.
